gameData.description: Historical and modern figures who have made a significant impact on the world.

keywords.hint: He developed the theory of relativity.
She was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.
He painted the Mona Lisa.
A pioneer in radioactivity research, she was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize.
He was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and political leader.
An English playwright, poet, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language.
An American Baptist minister and activist who became the most visible spokesperson and leader in the civil rights movement.
An Indian lawyer, anti-colonial nationalist, and political ethicist, who employed nonviolent resistance to lead the successful campaign for India's independence from British Rule.
An English mathematician, physicist, astronomer, theologian, and author who is widely recognised as one of the most influential scientists of all time.
An American aviation pioneer and author. She was the first female aviator to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean.
He was the co-founder, chairman, and CEO of Apple Inc.
An American talk show host, television producer, actress, author, and philanthropist.
An American former professional basketball player and businessman.
An American singer, songwriter, actress, and record producer.
The founder, CEO, and chief engineer at SpaceX; early stage investor, CEO, and product architect of Tesla, Inc.
An American professional tennis player. She has won 23 Grand Slam singles titles, the most by any player in the Open Era.
A Pakistani activist for female education and the youngest Nobel Prize laureate.
An American actor, producer, businessman, and former professional wrestler.
An American singer-songwriter. Her narrative songwriting, which often centers around her personal life, has received widespread critical praise and media coverage.
A Portuguese professional footballer who plays as a forward for Premier League club Manchester United and captains the Portugal national team.
An Argentine professional footballer who plays as a forward for Ligue 1 club Paris Saint-Germain and captains the Argentina national team.
An American entrepreneur, media proprietor, investor, and computer engineer. He is the founder and executive chairman of Amazon.
A Dutch Post-Impressionist painter who is among the most famous and influential figures in the history of Western art.
A Mexican painter known for her many portraits, self-portraits, and works inspired by the nature and artifacts of Mexico.
A Spanish painter, sculptor, printmaker, ceramicist and theatre designer who spent most of his adult life in France.
An American artist, film director, and producer who was a leading figure in the visual art movement known as pop art.
An American artist. She was known for her paintings of enlarged flowers, New York skyscrapers, and New Mexico landscapes.

A French painter, a founder of French Impressionist painting and the most consistent and prolific practitioner of the movement's philosophy of expressing one's perceptions before nature, especially as applied to plein air landscape painting.
An Italian sculptor, painter, architect and poet of the High Renaissance born in the Republic of Florence, who exerted an unparalleled influence on the development of Western art.
A Dutch draughtsman, painter, and printmaker.
A Spanish surrealist artist renowned for his technical skill, precise draftsmanship, and the striking and bizarre images in his work.
A German composer and pianist. A crucial figure in the transition between the Classical and Romantic eras in Western art music, he remains one of the most recognized and influential of all composers.
A prolific and influential composer of the Classical period.
A German composer and musician of the Baroque period.
An American singer and actor. Dubbed the 'King of Rock and Roll', he is regarded as one of the most significant cultural icons of the 20th century.
An American singer, songwriter, and dancer. Dubbed the 'King of Pop', he is regarded as one of the most significant cultural figures of the 20th century.
An American singer, songwriter, and actress. She is known for her continual reinvention and versatility in music production, songwriting, and visual presentation.
An English rock band, formed in Liverpool in 1960, that comprised John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr.
An American singer-songwriter, author and visual artist. Widely regarded as one of the greatest songwriters of all time, Dylan has been a major figure in popular culture for more than 50 years.
A British rock band formed in London in 1970. Their classic line-up was Freddie Mercury (lead vocals, piano), Brian May (guitar, vocals), Roger Taylor (drums, vocals), and John Deacon (bass).

An American musician, singer, and songwriter. Although his mainstream career spanned only four years, he is widely regarded as one of the most influential electric guitarists in the history of popular music, and one of a kind.
An English naturalist, geologist and biologist, best known for his contributions to the science of evolution.
An Italian astronomer, physicist and engineer, whose observations of the cosmos were revolutionary.
A Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, and futurist who is best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electrical system.
An English theoretical physicist, cosmologist, and author who was director of research at the Centre for Theoretical Cosmology at the University of Cambridge at the time of his death.
A Scottish-born inventor, scientist, and engineer who is credited with patenting the first practical telephone.
An American inventor and businessman who has been described as America's greatest inventor.

One of the Founding Fathers of the United States, he was also a leading author, printer, political theorist, politician, freemason, postmaster, scientist, inventor, humorist, civic activist, statesman, and diplomat.
A Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, inventor, and astronomer.
A Greek philosopher and polymath during the Classical period in Ancient Greece.
An Athenian philosopher during the Classical period in Ancient Greece, founder of the Platonist school of thought, and the Academy, the first institution of higher learning in the Western world.
A Greek philosopher from Athens who is credited as one of the founders of Western philosophy, and as being the first moral philosopher of the Western ethical tradition of thought.
An Italian mathematician from the Republic of Pisa, considered to be 'the most talented Western mathematician of the Middle Ages'.
An ancient Ionian Greek philosopher and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism.
A Greek mathematician, often referred to as the 'founder of geometry' or the 'father of geometry'.
An English mathematician, computer scientist, logician, cryptanalyst, philosopher, and theoretical biologist.
A Roman general and statesman who played a critical role in the events that led to the demise of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire.
The first Roman emperor, reigning from 27 BC until his death in AD 14.
A king of the ancient Greek kingdom of Macedon and a member of the Argead dynasty.
The founder and first Great Khan of the Mongol Empire, which became the largest contiguous empire in history after his death.
Queen of England and Ireland from 17 November 1558 until her death in 1603.
Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland from 20 June 1837 until her death in 1901.
A French military and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution and led several successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars.
An American lawyer and statesman who served as the 16th president of the United States from 1861 until his assassination in 1865.
An American political leader, military general, statesman, and Founding Father who served as the first president of the United States from 1789 to 1797.
An American politician who served as the 32nd president of the United States from 1933 until his death in 1945.
A British statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1940 to 1945, during the Second World War, and again from 1951 to 1955.

A Georgian revolutionary and Soviet politician who led the Soviet Union from the mid–1920s until 1953 as General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (1922–1952) and Premier (1941–1953).

A Chinese communist revolutionary who was the founder of the People's Republic of China, which he ruled as the chairman of the Communist Party of China from its establishment in 1949 until his death in 1976.
A Venetian merchant, explorer, and writer who travelled through Asia along the Silk Road between 1271 and 1295.
An Italian explorer and navigator who completed four voyages across the Atlantic Ocean, opening the way for European exploration and colonization of the Americas.
A Portuguese explorer who organised the Spanish expedition to the East Indies from 1519 to 1522, resulting in the first circumnavigation of the Earth, which was completed by Juan Sebastián Elcano.
A Portuguese explorer and the first European to reach India by sea.
A Norwegian explorer of polar regions. He was a key figure of the period known as the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration.
A French naval officer, explorer, conservationist, filmmaker, innovator, scientist, photographer, author and researcher who studied the sea and all forms of life in water.
A New Zealand mountaineer, explorer, and philanthropist. On 29 May 1953, he and Sherpa mountaineer Tenzing Norgay became the first climbers confirmed to have reached the summit of Mount Everest.
An American astronaut and aeronautical engineer, and the first person to walk on the Moon.
The presumed author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems that are the central works of ancient Greek literature.
An ancient Roman poet of the Augustan period. He wrote three of the most famous poems in Latin literature: the Eclogues (or Bucolics), the Georgics, and the epic Aeneid.

An Italian poet, writer and philosopher. His Divine Comedy, originally called Comedìa and later christened Divina by Giovanni Boccaccio, is widely considered one of the most important poems of the Middle Ages and the greatest literary work in the Italian language.
An English poet and author. Widely considered the greatest English poet of the Middle Ages, he is best known for The Canterbury Tales.
An English novelist known primarily for her six major novels, which interpret, critique and comment upon the British landed gentry at the end of the 18th century.
An English writer and social critic. He created some of the world's best-known fictional characters and is regarded by many as the greatest novelist of the Victorian era.
An American writer, humorist, entrepreneur, publisher, and lecturer.
An English novelist, essayist, journalist and critic. His work is characterised by lucid prose, biting social criticism, opposition to totalitarianism, and outspoken support of democratic socialism.
An American novelist, short-story writer, journalist, and sportsman.
An English writer, considered one of the most important modernist 20th-century authors and also a pioneer in the use of stream of consciousness as a narrative device.

A British author, philanthropist, film producer, television producer, and screenwriter. She is best known for writing the Harry Potter fantasy series, which has won multiple awards and sold more than 500 million copies, becoming the best-selling book series in history.
An American writer, poet, editor, and literary critic. Poe is best known for his poetry and short stories, particularly his tales of mystery and the macabre.
An American poet. Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts, into a prominent family with strong ties to its community.
An American poet. His work was initially published in England before it was published in the United States.
An American poet, singer, memoirist, and civil rights activist.
An American social reformer and women's rights activist who played a pivotal role in the women's suffrage movement.

An American abolitionist and political activist. Born into slavery, Tubman escaped and subsequently made some thirteen missions to rescue approximately seventy enslaved people, family and friends, using the network of antislavery activists and safe houses known as the Underground Railroad.
An American activist in the civil rights movement best known for her pivotal role in the Montgomery bus boycott.

An American political figure, diplomat and activist. She served as the First Lady of the United States from March 4, 1933, to April 12, 1945, during her husband President Franklin D. Roosevelt's four terms in office, making her the longest-serving First Lady of the United States.
A pioneering American nurse who founded the American Red Cross.
An English social reformer, statistician and the founder of modern nursing.
A South African Anglican cleric and theologian known for his work as an anti-apartheid and human rights activist.
The spiritual leader of the Tibetan people.
An American business magnate, software developer, investor, and philanthropist. He is a co-founder of Microsoft Corporation.
An American business magnate, investor, and philanthropist. He is currently the chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway.
An American media magnate, internet entrepreneur, and philanthropist. He is known for co-founding Facebook, Inc. and serves as its chairman, chief executive officer, and controlling shareholder.
An English business magnate, investor, and author. In the 1970s he founded the Virgin Group, which today controls more than 400 companies in various fields.
An American entrepreneur, animator, writer, voice actor, and film producer.
An American industrialist and business magnate, founder of the Ford Motor Company, and chief developer of the assembly line technique of mass production.
A Scottish-American industrialist and philanthropist.
An American business magnate and philanthropist. He is widely considered the wealthiest American of all time, and the richest person in modern history.
A German philosopher and one of the central Enlightenment thinkers.
A German philosopher, cultural critic, composer, poet, and philologist whose work has exerted a profound influence on modern intellectual history.
A French-born philosopher, mathematician, and scientist who spent a large portion of his working life in the Dutch Republic.

A Genevan philosopher, writer, and composer. His political philosophy influenced the progress of the Enlightenment throughout Europe, as well as aspects of the French Revolution and the development of modern political, economic, and educational thought.
An English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of Enlightenment thinkers and commonly known as the 'Father of Liberalism'.
A Scottish Enlightenment philosopher, historian, economist, and essayist, who is best known today for his highly influential system of philosophical empiricism, skepticism, and naturalism.
A Chinese philosopher and politician of the Spring and Autumn period who was traditionally considered the paragon of Chinese sages.
An ancient Chinese philosopher and writer. He is the reputed author of the Tao Te Ching, the founder of philosophical Taoism, and a deity in religious Taoism and traditional Chinese religions.
An English film director, producer, and screenwriter. He is one of the most influential and extensively studied filmmakers in the history of cinema.
An American film director, producer, screenwriter, and photographer. He is frequently cited as one of the most influential filmmakers in cinematic history.
A Japanese film director and screenwriter who directed 30 films in a career spanning 57 years.

An American film director, producer, and screenwriter. He is considered one of the founding pioneers of the New Hollywood era, as well as one of the most popular directors and producers in film history.

An American film director, producer, screenwriter, and actor. One of the major figures of the New Hollywood era, he is widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential directors in film history.

An American film director, screenwriter, producer, and actor. His films are characterized by nonlinear storylines, satirical subject matter, an aestheticization of violence, extended scenes of dialogue, ensemble casts, references to popular culture, and a wide variety of music.
A British-American film director, producer, and screenwriter. His films have grossed over $5 billion worldwide, and have garnered 11 Academy Awards from 36 nominations.

A Canadian film director, producer, screenwriter, editor, and environmentalist. He is a major figure in the post-New Hollywood era and is considered one of the most innovative filmmakers in the industry.

An American film director, producer, screenwriter, and entrepreneur. He is best known for creating the Star Wars and Indiana Jones franchises and founding Lucasfilm, LucasArts, and Industrial Light & Magic.
An Italian sculptor, painter, architect and poet of the High Renaissance.
A Dutch draughtsman, painter, and printmaker.
A Dutch Baroque Period painter who specialized in domestic interior scenes of middle-class life.
A French painter whose brief career spurred the revival of interest in colour and movement, as seen in the tradition of Correggio and Rubens.
A French Romantic artist regarded from the outset of his career as the leader of the French Romantic school.
A French post-Impressionist artist. He is best known for devising the painting techniques known as chromoluminarism and pointillism.
A Renaissance-era mathematician and astronomer who formulated a model of the universe that placed the Sun rather than Earth at the center of the universe.
An Italian astronomer, physicist and engineer, whose observations of the cosmos were revolutionary.
An English mathematician, physicist, astronomer, theologian, and author who is widely recognised as one of the most influential scientists of all time.

gameData.description: Creatures from the animal kingdom, including mammals, insects, and marine life.

keywords.hint: This large cat is known as the 'king of the jungle'.
A highly intelligent marine mammal known for its playful behavior.
Famous for its long-distance seasonal migration.
The largest land animal, known for its long trunk and large ears.
A flightless bird that lives in the Southern Hemisphere, primarily in Antarctica.
A large predatory fish found in coastal waters of all major oceans.
The tallest living terrestrial animal, known for its extremely long neck.
A flying insect known for producing honey and pollinating flowers.
The largest animal on Earth, a marine mammal.
A marsupial from Australia, known for its powerful hind legs and pouch.
A bear native to south central China, known for its black and white coat and diet of bamboo.
A reptile that lives in the ocean and has a bony or cartilaginous shell.
A great ape native to the rainforests of Indonesia and Malaysia, known for its long arms and reddish-brown hair.
A free-swimming marine animal with a gelatinous umbrella-shaped bell and trailing tentacles.
A small beetle with a round, often brightly colored, body.
The largest cat species, known for its distinctive orange coat with dark vertical stripes.
A large ape native to the forests of central Sub-Saharan Africa.
An African equine with distinctive black-and-white striped coats.
A large bear native to the Arctic Circle, known for its white fur.
A soft-bodied, eight-limbed mollusc of the order Octopoda.
A small, brightly colored fish that lives in symbiosis with sea anemones.
A small bird known for its ability to hover in mid-air by rapidly flapping its wings.
A domesticated bovine animal, raised for its milk, meat, and leather.
A domesticated animal raised for its meat, such as bacon and pork.
A domesticated ruminant animal, raised for its wool, meat, and milk.
A hardy domesticated ruminant animal, raised for its milk, meat, and hair.
A domesticated fowl, raised for its eggs and meat.
A domesticated perissodactyl mammal, used for riding, racing, and to carry and pull loads.
A domesticated carnivorous mammal that typically has a long snout, an acute sense of smell, and a barking, howling, or whining voice.
A small domesticated carnivorous mammal with soft fur, a short snout, and retractable claws.
A burrowing, plant-eating mammal with long ears, long hind legs, and a short tail.
A small, orange-colored freshwater fish, often kept as a pet in a bowl or aquarium.
A brightly colored bird, often kept as a pet, that is able to mimic human speech.
A small, stout-bodied rodent with large cheek pouches, often kept as a pet.
A slow-moving reptile, enclosed in a bony or leathery shell, that can live on land or in water.
A reptile that typically has a long body and tail, four legs, and a tapering snout.
A long, limbless reptile that has no eyelids, a short tail, and jaws that are capable of considerable extension.
A large bird of prey with a massive hooked bill and long broad wings, known for its keen sight.
A waterbird with a broad blunt bill, short legs, webbed feet, and a waddling gait.
A male peafowl, which has a crested head and a very long ornate tail that has eyelike markings and can be erected and fanned out in display.
A large waterbird with a long flexible neck, short legs, webbed feet, a broad bill, and typically all-white plumage.
A stout seed- or fruit-eating bird with a small head, short legs, and a cooing voice, typically having a grey and white plumage.
A large perching bird with mostly glossy black plumage, a stout bill, and a loud, harsh call.
A large heavily built crow with mainly black plumage.

A large bird of prey with the head and neck more or less bare of feathers, feeding chiefly on carrion and reputed to gather with others in anticipation of the death of a sick or injured animal or person.
A bird of prey with broad rounded wings and a long tail, typically taking prey by surprise with a short chase.
A tall, long-legged, long-necked bird, typically with white or grey plumage and often with a patch of bare red skin on the head.
A nocturnal bird of prey with large forward-facing eyes surrounded by facial disks, a hooked beak, and typically a loud call.
A bird with a strong bill and a stiff tail, that climbs tree trunks to find insects and drums on the wood to mark territory.
A brightly colored bird with a long, sharp beak, found near water and feeding on fish.
A small insectivorous songbird with a red breast, found in Europe, Asia, and North America.
A large edible fish that is a popular game fish, much prized for its pink flesh. Salmon are native to tributaries of the North Atlantic (genus Salmo) and Pacific Ocean (genus Oncorhynchus).
A saltwater fish that belongs to the tribe Thunnini, a subgrouping of the Scombridae (mackerel) family.
The common name for the demersal fish genus Gadus, belonging to the family Gadidae.
A species of freshwater fish in the salmon family Salmonidae.
A common name applied to a number of different species of pelagic fish, mostly from the family Scombridae.
A small, oily forage fish.
A small, common forage fish of the family Engraulidae.
A forage fish, mostly belonging to the family of Clupeidae.
A group of sea rays, which are cartilaginous fish related to sharks.
A member of a family of omnivorous freshwater fish that live in South American rivers, floodplains, lakes and reservoirs.
A family of ray-finned fish, Pomacanthidae, found on shallow reefs in the tropical Atlantic, Indian, and mostly western Pacific oceans.
A large, predatory fish characterized by a long, flat, pointed bill.
A large, predatory, ray-finned fish known for its fearsome appearance and ferocious behaviour.
A tailless amphibian with a short-bodied, stout build, prominent eyes, and long, powerful hind limbs adapted for leaping.

A group of amphibians typically characterized by a lizard-like appearance, with slender bodies, blunt snouts, short limbs projecting at right angles to the body, and the presence of a tail in both larvae and adults.
A certain kind of frog, particularly a number of species in the family Bufonidae, that are characterized by dry, leathery skin, short legs, and large bumps covering the parotoid glands.
A salamander in the subfamily Pleurodelinae.
A large semiaquatic reptile that lives throughout the tropics in Africa, Asia, the Americas and Australia.
A large reptile in the Crocodylia order in the genus Alligator of the family Alligatoridae.
A distinctive and highly specialized clade of Old World lizards with 202 species described as of June 2015.
A genus of herbivorous lizards that are native to tropical areas of Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Caribbean.
A small lizard of a large family found in warm climates, having suction pads on its feet that enable it to climb on smooth vertical surfaces.
A species of lizard found in the Indonesian islands of Komodo, Rinca, Flores, and Gili Motang.
A venomous snake of a family (Elapidae) that is native to Asia and Africa and is characterized by a hood of skin which it can expand.
A genus of constricting snakes in the Pythonidae family native to the tropics and subtropics of the Eastern Hemisphere.
A species of large, heavy-bodied snake that is frequently kept and bred in captivity.
A eusocial insect of the family Formicidae and, along with the related wasps and bees, belong to the order Hymenoptera.
A winged insect closely related to wasps and ants, known for their role in pollination and, in the case of the best-known bee species, the European honey bee, for producing honey and beeswax.
A winged insect which is neither a bee nor an ant.
A group of insects that form the order Coleoptera, in the superorder Endopterygota.
A primarily diurnal insect of the order Lepidoptera, which also includes moths.
A paraphyletic group of insects that includes all members of the order Lepidoptera that are not butterflies.
Insects of the order Diptera, the name being derived from the Greek δι- di- 'two', and πτερόν pteron 'wing'.
A group of about 3,500 species of small insects within the family Culicidae (from the Latin culex meaning 'gnat').
Insects of the order Blattodea, which also includes termites.
An insect belonging to the order Odonata, infraorder Anisoptera.
A group of insects belonging to the suborder Caelifera.
An insect belonging to the order Orthoptera.
A large, heavy, mammal that walks on the soles of its feet, with thick fur and a very short tail.
A wild carnivorous mammal which is the largest member of the dog family, living and hunting in packs.
A carnivorous mammal of the dog family with a pointed snout and a bushy tail, proverbial for its cunning.
A hoofed grazing or browsing animal, with branched bony antlers that are shed annually and typically borne only by the male.
A large deer with palmate antlers, a sloping back, and a drooping muzzle, native to northern Eurasia and North America.
A humpbacked shaggy-haired wild ox native to North America and Europe.
A mammal whose forelimbs form webbed wings, making them the only mammals naturally capable of true and sustained flight.
A very large marine mammal with a streamlined hairless body, a horizontal tail fin, and a blowhole on top of the head for breathing.
A carnivorous aquatic mammal with a streamlined body and feet developed as flippers, that returns to land to breed or rest.
A species of great ape native to the forest and savannah of tropical Africa.
A large ape native to the forests of central Sub-Saharan Africa.
A great ape native to the rainforests of Indonesia and Malaysia, known for its long arms and reddish-brown hair.
A large Old World monkey with a long, doglike muzzle and large canine teeth.
A small to medium-sized primate that typically has a long tail, most kinds of which live in trees in tropical countries.
An arboreal primate with a pointed snout and typically a long tail, found only in Madagascar.
A small, slender, long-armed ape of the family Hylobatidae.
A large West African baboon with a red and blue face, a yellow beard, and a red rump.

gameData.description: Major cities and capitals from around the world.

keywords.hint: The capital of France, known for the Eiffel Tower.
The capital of Japan, a bustling metropolis known for its Imperial Palace.
The capital of Egypt, famous for the nearby Giza pyramid complex.
The capital of Italy, home to the Colosseum and the Vatican City.
The capital of the United Kingdom, known for the River Thames and the Tower of London.
The capital of China, home to the Forbidden City and the Great Wall.
The capital of Russia, known for the Kremlin and Red Square.
The capital of the United States, home to the White House and the Lincoln Memorial.
The capital of Australia, known for its large man-made lake, Lake Burley Griffin.
The capital of Canada, located in the province of Ontario.
The capital of Brazil, known for its unique modern architecture.
The capital of India, a bustling city with a rich history.
The capital of Mexico, one of the oldest cities in the Americas.
The capital of Argentina, famous for its tango music and dance.
The capital of Germany, known for the Brandenburg Gate and the Berlin Wall Memorial.
The capital of Spain, home to the Royal Palace and the Prado Museum.
The capital of South Korea, a megacity where modern skyscrapers, high-tech subways and pop culture meet Buddhist temples, palaces and street markets.
The capital of Thailand, known for its ornate shrines and vibrant street life.
The capital of Saudi Arabia, a modern city in the heart of the Arabian peninsula.
The capital of Turkey, a modern European city with a rich history.
The capital of Greece, the heart of Ancient Greece, a powerful civilization and empire.
The most populous city in the United States, known for its iconic landmarks such as the Statue of Liberty and Times Square.
The largest city in California, home to Hollywood and the entertainment industry.
A major city in Illinois, known for its architecture and deep-dish pizza.
A large metropolis in Texas, known for its role in the space exploration industry.
The most populous city in Canada, known for the CN Tower and its diverse culture.
The second-most populous city in Canada, known for its French colonial history and cobblestone streets.
A major city in western Canada, located in the Lower Mainland region of British Columbia.
The capital of Mexico, a densely populated, high-altitude city.
A city in western Mexico and the capital of the state of Jalisco.
A major industrial city in northern Mexico.
The capital of France, known for its art, fashion, gastronomy and culture.
The capital of England and the United Kingdom, is a 21st-century city with history stretching back to Roman times.
The capital of Spain, is a city of elegant boulevards and expansive, manicured parks such as the Buen Retiro.
The capital city of Italy, is a sprawling, cosmopolitan city with nearly 3,000 years of globally influential art, architecture and culture on display.
Germany’s capital, dates to the 13th century. Reminders of the city's turbulent 20th-century history include its Holocaust memorial and the Berlin Wall's graffitied remains.
Austria’s capital, lies in the country’s east on the Danube River.
Capital city of the Czech Republic, is bisected by the Vltava River.
Hungary’s capital, is bisected by the River Danube.
The capital of Poland, is a city of rich history and culture.
The capital city of Ukraine, is a major industrial, scientific, educational and cultural center of Eastern Europe.
Japan’s busy capital, mixes the ultramodern and the traditional, from skyscrapers to historic temples.
India’s capital territory, is a massive metropolitan area in the country’s north.
China's most populous city, is a major commercial and financial hub.
The capital city of Bangladesh, is a major center of the country's economy, politics and culture.
China’s sprawling capital, has history stretching back 3 millennia.
Formerly Bombay, a densely populated city on India’s west coast.
A large port city and commercial center on the Japanese island of Honshu.
The capital of the Pakistani province of Sindh. It is the most populous city in Pakistan, and seventh-most-populous city proper in the world.
The capital of the Philippines, is a densely populated bayside city on the island of Luzon.
The capital of South Korea, is a huge metropolis where modern skyscrapers, high-tech subways and pop culture meet Buddhist temples, palaces and street markets.
Brazil's vibrant financial center, is among the world's most populous cities.
Argentina’s big, cosmopolitan capital city.
A huge seaside city in Brazil, famed for its Copacabana and Ipanema beaches.
Colombia's sprawling, high-altitude capital.
The capital of Peru, lies on the country's arid Pacific coast.
The capital and largest city of Chile.
The capital city of Brazil’s Minas Gerais state.
The capital of Brazil’s northeastern state of Bahia.
The largest city in Nigeria and one of the most populous urban agglomerations.
The capital and the largest city of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
The capital of Egypt and the largest city in the Arab world.
The largest city in South Africa, and is one of the 50 largest urban areas in the world.
The capital and largest city of Kenya.
The capital and largest city of Ethiopia.
The largest city of Morocco.
The largest city and former capital of Tanzania.
The economic capital of Ivory Coast and one of the most populous French-speaking cities in Africa.
The capital of New South Wales and one of Australia's largest cities.
The coastal capital of the southeastern Australian state of Victoria.
The capital of Queensland, is a large city on the Brisbane River.
The capital of Western Australia, sits where the Swan River meets the southwest coast.
The most populous city in New Zealand, located in the North Island.
The capital of New Zealand, sits near the North Island’s southernmost point on the Cook Strait.
A city on the east coast of New Zealand's South Island, known for its English heritage.
The capital and largest city of Papua New Guinea.
A city in the Middle East, located on a plateau in the Judaean Mountains between the Mediterranean and the Dead Sea.
The capital of Syria, it is also the country's largest city.
The largest city in the Mount Lebanon Governorate of Lebanon. It is believed to have been first occupied between 8800 and 7000 BC and continuously inhabited since 5000 BC.
The capital of Greece, is one of the world's oldest cities, with a recorded history spanning over 3,400 years.
The capital city of Italy, is a sprawling, cosmopolitan city with nearly 3,000 years of globally influential art, architecture and culture on display.
A major city in Turkey that straddles Europe and Asia across the Bosphorus Strait.
A city on the Ganges river in northern India.

The capital city of the fictional Land of Oz in L. Frank Baum's Oz books.

A region of J. R. R. Tolkien's fictional Middle-earth, described in The Lord of the Rings and other works.

A historic and archaeological city in southern Jordan.

gameData.description: Dishes, ingredients, and cuisines from around the world.

keywords.hint: A popular dish of Italian origin, consisting of a usually round, flat base of leavened wheat-based dough topped with tomatoes, cheese, and often various other ingredients.
A Japanese dish of prepared vinegared rice, usually with some sugar and salt, accompanying a variety of ingredients, such as seafood, vegetables, and occasionally tropical fruits.
A traditional Mexican dish consisting of a small hand-sized corn or wheat tortilla topped with a filling.
A sandwich consisting of one or more cooked patties of ground meat, usually beef, placed inside a sliced bread roll or bun.
A staple food of traditional Italian cuisine, with the first reference dating to 1154 in Sicily.
A buttery, flaky, viennoiserie pastry of Austrian origin, but mostly associated with France.
A dish consisting of a mixture of small pieces of food, usually vegetables or fruit.

A cultivar group of the species Capsicum annuum.
A leafy green flowering plant native to central and western Asia.
A green, leafy, cruciferous vegetable that is rich in nutrients.

A sweet, mild fruit, the flesh of which is eaten.
The fruit of many plants of the genus Prunus, and is a fleshy drupe (stone fruit).

gameData.description: Common items found in a household.

keywords.hint: A small piece of shaped metal with incisions cut to fit the wards of a particular lock, which is inserted into a lock and turned to open or close it.
A small, flat case for holding money, credit cards, and other personal items.
A device consisting of a circular canopy of cloth on a folding metal frame supported by a central rod, used as protection against rain or sometimes sun.
